body: Just pushed removal from InternalDataSerializer.SANCTIONED_SERIALIZABLES_DEPENDENCIES_PATTERN
@upthewaterspout / @WireBaron Can you re-review this, please?
I like this idea, but without some updates we can't merge it. @afTrolle are you interested in doing the work to get this mergeable?

precheckin green

I've pushed some new changes:

* DistributedRestoreSystemProperties now invokes RestoreSystemProperties before and after via overriding the access modifiers on those methods instead of using reflection
* DistributedRestoreSystemProperties now records the beforeVmCount (number of VMs that were present for before) and asserts that the afterVmCount is not greater -- because that would mean that one or more VMs were not captured for the before
The build check failed because of spotless
precheckin green

@dschneider-pivotal  If there are specific messages that need to avoid deserializing values we need to address these individually.  As it stands any message using DataSerializer.readObject() is subject to receiving a PdxInstance if a PdxSerializer is installed and happens to affect the value in question.  Our methods were not implemented with that possibility in mind.

GfshCommand is still internal. Which one is the public GfshCommand?
@jinmeiliao This is a part of the overall change, where this PR only prepares GfshCommand to be public before it can actually be public.
I'd say +1, but reword the commit message since you haven't actually made `GfshCommand` public yet.

Updated by allowing InterruptedException to be thrown back to caller.

In addition, updated the Test Category to include LuceneTest and used logger to display rebalance activities.

I've noticed that the `equals` was a clear copy-paste from another class and that as a result, no instance of `LinkedStructSet` will equal itself.  In an effort to not get side-tracked from what I was working on, I've left this existing behavior alone, to be fixed in a future ticket.
precheckin green other than spotless.  My love, my enemy.
I am either going to have to rework this significantly or will choose not to redo it after Dan does work on an `AuthorizingCache`. Closing.

I think this should really have an integration test using the `GfshParser` or `GfshCommandRule`, but I'm having trouble injecting test classes into the path to be picked up by a standard instantiation of `Gfsh`.  If anyone has any insight into how to do that cleanly, I'd love to hear it.

The `MockExtensionCommands` appear to be picked up, perhaps by some `META-INF` magic, but I was unsuccessful in my attempts to reproduce the behavior.

Sorry for such a large diff -- these tags get everywhere, but I feel the renaming has value since this there are many places where it seems that logging is intended bug inadvertently suppressed.

Because this commit is, as the correction of a perceived bug, re-enabling many suppressed logging statements at coarse log levels, we may wish to make a note in the next release that logs may be more verbose than before.
@sboorlagadda We have made the changes per your suggestion.
Lots of weirdness in the git history. I'm closing, I'll clean that up, and then re-open a PR.
After speaking with Jinmei, I went ahead and made the test corrections on her behalf.

@jdeppe-pivotal Maybe, but I think not?  The things to note:

* The vast majority of these markers are only applied at the TRACE level, and much of the remaining marker usage is at the DEBUG level.  It is unlikely that these usages would be considered common.
* The only marker documented is `GEMFIRE_VERBOSE` (changed in this commit to document `GEODE_VERBOSE`).
* This documentation concludes with "Typically, its more useful to simply enable DEBUG or TRACE on certain classes or packages instead of for the entire Geode product. However, this setting can be used for internal debugging purposes if all other debugging methods fail."  Explicitly, the intent is for internal debugging.
* Consequently, the marker definitions are themselves in an `internal` package, even tough they present a public profile.

I agree that it's a strange grey area.  But I also thing the root cause of this bug -- that non-debug level logs were being improperly suppressed -- was due to poor naming in these markers.

I suppose there's no inherent need for the marker's field name to match it's string name / the string used in the `log4j2.xml`.  I could try to coerce the old marker strings into the new marker lists.  But since several markers were split to distinguish `*_VERBOSE` debug level logging and `*_MARKER` coarser level logging, it might be awkward to map from the old to the new.  But I could give it a go, if you or anyone else feels strongly about it.
This is a (kind of) cherry pick version of GEODE-4913 fix onto rel/1.5.0.
@PurelyApplied  - I made both of the changes you suggested, along with the rest of the review comments. Does this look good now?

The description of the PR is misleading -- I thought for a second you were removing all uses of `Wait.pause()` _in the codebase!_

Were you able to reproduce the failure before removing the `Wait.pause()` calls?

@galen-pivotal The `Wait.pause()` calls were entirely unnecessary: someone had previously switched to synchronous invocations so the operations in the VMs had already completed by the time `Wait.pause()` was called. Their removal introduced no new failures.
is this to catch the acceptance test failures? sometimes I see the test setup fails and it is not during shutdown.

Yes, this is intended to help debug AcceptanceTest failures. We think that the failures are caused by a dirty environment, so this should help find the cause of the dirty environment from previous tests failing to shutdown properly.
Getting some strange behavior in `gradle` when run with the initial compile tasks / `./gradlew --rerun-tasks`.

pre-checkin is green except the failure regarding GEODE-4963
Fixes for all review items have been pushed.
precheckin is good

> If we are shutting down the in-process state is left being set to true
> so that lockers won't get a spurious conflict exception from the grantor
> and will retry their commits with a new grantor when one is created.

<s>Which in-process state is left set to true?</s>

Oh, I see now, if cancel is in progress then execution will be rejected and we won't set `processingDepartures` back to false.

> Which in-process state is left set to true?

The new boolean added by this change-set
Closing due to inactivity.

> I'm concerned that any thread that calls DLockGrantor.handleLockRequest() potentially being blocked indefinitely during shutdown -- can this block shutdown or restart?

Lots of threads get blocked in all sorts of situations during shutdown.  This allows things like primary bucket failover and lock grantor recovery to happen.  There are, for instance, a number of other places in the dlock service itself that already wait for grantor recovery during lock acquisition or release.
Precheckin green.
Precheckin green, excepting a failure due to GEODE-4980.
Precheckin green.
Precheckin is green
how much change do we have without renaming of the markers?

Not as much but still quite a bit.  Because of the non-descriptive naming, many of the tags were improperly used in INFO / WARNING / ERROR level log statements -- the core issue this bug ticket is addressing.  Each of these log statements require a new `LogMarker`.  (An alternative solution would be to remove these tags altogether, but the diff would be the same.)

Many log statements were pathologically locked, such as `if (debugIsEnabled) { logger.trace(...); }`.  These were corrected to check the log level in question.

Other minor improvements noted in the commit message.
Pretty sure all my build problems were because I was careless about my environment.  Running one last precheckin now...

precheckin green.

I merged this with `develop` locally to rerun precheckin and see if it could be pulled in.  It looks like there are a lot of test failures surrounding rolling upgrade, since the `ExpiryTask` shows up on the wire.  With the class repackaged, members with different versions don't know how to deserialize the other's type.

See the following classes:
```
org.apache.geode.internal.cache.TxCommitMessageBackwardCompatibilityDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.internal.cache.rollingupgrade.RollingUpgrade2DUnitTest
org.apache.geode.security.ClientAuthenticationDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.security.ClientAuthenticationPart2DUnitTest
```

I think it's only showing up on the wire in the tests' lambdas, not internally in production code.  These lambdas appear to be in the `JUnit4DistributedTestCase` and not the tests themselves.  It may be enough to rework these test classes using the `@ClusterStartupRule` to replace the extension of the `*TestCase`.

Hope everything's fine now, please let me know if something's missing!.
